articles.headline: Fox News to Add Another Hour of Right-Wing Talk as Biden Takes Office
articles.snippet: The anchor Martha MacCallum will be replaced by a conservative host at 7 p.m., and CNN will expand Jake Tapper’s afternoon show.
articles.abstract: The anchor Martha MacCallum will be replaced by a conservative host at 7 p.m., and CNN will expand Jake Tapper’s afternoon show.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch’s cable news channel said on Monday that it would revamp its daytime lineup starting next week, the week of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s inauguration, adding another hour of right-wing opinion as a lead-in to its prime-time stars Tucker Carlson and Sean Hannity.

articles.headline: An Urgent Reckoning for the Trump Brand
articles.snippet: Companies and institutions are shunning President Trump and some associates after the attack on the U.S. Capitol. The Trump family business, built on luxury hospitality, is contemplating a reinvention.
articles.abstract: Companies and institutions are shunning President Trump and some associates after the attack on the U.S. Capitol. The Trump family business, built on luxury hospitality, is contemplating a reinvention.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the span of four days, President Trump’s family business has lost its online store, the buzz from Mr. Trump’s promotional tweets about its luxury resorts and bragging rights as host to one of the world’s most prestigious golf tournaments.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, Ben Protess and Steve Eder

articles.headline: State Capitols ‘on High Alert,’ Fearing More Violence
articles.snippet: Officials around the country are bracing for any spillover from last week’s violent assault on the U.S. Capitol. State legislatures already have become targets for protesters in recent days.
articles.abstract: Officials around the country are bracing for any spillover from last week’s violent assault on the U.S. Capitol. State legislatures already have become targets for protesters in recent days.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was opening day of the 2021 legislative session, and the perimeter of the Georgia State Capitol on Monday was bristling with state police officers in full camouflage gear, most of them carrying tactical rifles.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Mike Baker

articles.headline: Companies Pull Back Political Giving Following Capitol Violence
articles.snippet: AT&T and Marriott were among companies that will stop campaign contributions to lawmakers who objected to certifying the election. Other companies, such as JPMorgan, paused all political donations.
articles.abstract: AT&T and Marriott were among companies that will stop campaign contributions to lawmakers who objected to certifying the election. Other companies, such as JPMorgan, paused all political donations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Days after a pro-Trump mob attacked the United States Capitol, some of America’s biggest companies said they would pause political giving as they rethink their support of certain lawmakers and their own involvement in politics more broadly.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly, Emily Flitter and Shane Goldmacher

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Pursues at Least 150 Suspects in Capitol Riot
articles.snippet: Federal law enforcement officials have embarked on a nationwide manhunt as they grapple with the fallout from the government’s failure to protect the Capitol.
articles.abstract: Federal law enforcement officials have embarked on a nationwide manhunt as they grapple with the fallout from the government’s failure to protect the Capitol.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department and the F.B.I. have embarked on a nationwide manhunt to track down scores of people who attacked the Capitol last week, according to law enforcement officials, as they grapple with the fallout from the widespread government failure to protect the building.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: House Sets Impeachment Vote to Charge Trump With Incitement
articles.snippet: Democrats are planning a Tuesday vote to formally call on the vice president to wrest power from President Trump and a Wednesday impeachment vote if he does not.
articles.abstract: Democrats are planning a Tuesday vote to formally call on the vice president to wrest power from President Trump and a Wednesday impeachment vote if he does not.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats introduced an article of impeachment against President Trump on Monday for his role in inflaming a mob that attacked the Capitol, scheduling a Wednesday vote to charge the president with “inciting violence against the government of the United States” if Vice President Mike Pence refused to strip him of power first.

articles.headline: Fringe Groups Splinter Online After Facebook and Twitter Bans
articles.snippet: Tracking what may be planned in the coming days could become even more difficult as the groups take to lesser-known networks and apps that can’t be easily monitored.
articles.abstract: Tracking what may be planned in the coming days could become even more difficult as the groups take to lesser-known networks and apps that can’t be easily monitored.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the Telegram messaging app, there were calls for armed marches on state capitols and the offices of tech companies like Google, Facebook and Twitter, starting on Jan. 16.

articles.headline: How White Evangelical Christians Fused With Trump Extremism
articles.snippet: A potent mix of grievance and religious fervor has turbocharged the support among Trump loyalists, many of whom describe themselves as participants in a kind of holy war.
articles.abstract: A potent mix of grievance and religious fervor has turbocharged the support among Trump loyalists, many of whom describe themselves as participants in a kind of holy war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Before self-proclaimed members of the far-right group the Proud Boys marched toward the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, they stopped to kneel in the street and prayed in the name of Jesus.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham

articles.headline: Lost Passwords Lock Millionaires Out of Their Bitcoin Fortunes
articles.snippet: Bitcoin owners are getting rich because the cryptocurrency has soared. But what happens when you can’t tap that wealth because you forgot the password to your digital wallet?
articles.abstract: Bitcoin owners are getting rich because the cryptocurrency has soared. But what happens when you can’t tap that wealth because you forgot the password to your digital wallet?
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: ‘An Epiphany Moment’ for Corporate Political Donors May Have Arrived
articles.snippet: As companies put their donations to candidates on hold, they should reassess political giving entirely, making the halt permanent.
articles.abstract: As companies put their donations to candidates on hold, they should reassess political giving entirely, making the halt permanent.
articles.lead_paragraph: As companies from Coca-Cola to Amazon to Citigroup appear to be tripping over one another to declare that they are “pausing” or “reassessing” donations to Republicans who sought to overturn the election — and, in some cases, suspending giving to both parties — they might want to look at a company that didn’t say anything.

articles.headline: Sheldon Adelson, Billionaire Donor to G.O.P. and Israel, Is Dead at 87
articles.snippet: Mr. Adelson drew a cornucopia of cash from his empire of casinos and resort hotels and poured money into right-wing causes.
articles.abstract: Mr. Adelson drew a cornucopia of cash from his empire of casinos and resort hotels and poured money into right-wing causes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sheldon G. Adelson, a cabdriver’s son who built the world’s largest empire of casinos and resort hotels in Las Vegas, Macau, Singapore and other gambling meccas and used his vast wealth to promote right-wing political agendas in America and Israel, died on Monday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 87.

articles.headline: ‘I Could Just Vanish’: In Kabul, Pocket Notes to Prevent Anonymous Death
articles.snippet: As violence engulfs them, some Afghans carry notes with their names, blood types and relatives’ phone numbers in case they are killed or severely wounded.
articles.abstract: As violence engulfs them, some Afghans carry notes with their names, blood types and relatives’ phone numbers in case they are killed or severely wounded.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Tareq Qassemi, a bookseller, lost a close friend to a suicide bombing that killed 80 civilians in Kabul one scorching summer day. Four years later, he still mourns his friend, but also the nameless Afghans who perished with him.
articles.byline: By David Zucchino and Fatima Faizi
